text: Fox already have the rights to X-Men and Deadpool, even now they're expanding that universe with enough ideas to last them a long time. It's unfortunate that they couldn't make a deal with Marvel like Sony did, that way not only would TFF have had their own films but the potential to be in other installments like another Avengers movie, making even more money than what they hope to get out of this reboot attempt, and in the wake of AOU fans would have been more than happy to pay if it was part of the MCU. text: So, majority of people has huge problems with the liberties with the source material which this movie takes, and they outrageously demand for this movie to flop, so in the theory, the movie rights for the Fantastic Four will go back to marvel? Yeah, and also, that majority, I'm pretty sure, was completely fine with what Marvel did wit the Mandarin in Iron Man 3, and I'm not even talking about that trivial plot twist in the movie, I'm talking about how overall he was presented. Making The Mandarin a middle-eastern¬†terrorist nationalist, believe me, is far more disrespectful than making Doctor Doom a blogger. Yeah, and I'm pretty sure, that majority thought that movies like Iron Man 2 and Iron Man 3 respected the source material on which they were based on, while even the directors of those movie-abominations stated that they don't respect the source material. Jon Favreau said that doesn't wants to adapt the Demon in a Bottle story, "cuz it's too dark", and incompetent hack Shane Black said in front of dozens of people that Iron Man doesn't have good rouges gallery. And yet people still enjoy those shitfets, because it's "Marvel". Well, what can I say? People are hypocrites. I believe in you, Trank, bring it on.

text: I'm Black American & when i was a kid back in the 70's & started buying & collecting comics, I have a problem with how Hollywood is changing the ethnic group of character's! Mind you this may spark controversy to some that may agree or not; however, Johnny & Sue were blood brother's & sister's & their father' Franklin' was of the same race! OK...DareDevil the villain known as " King Pin '' played by ' Michael Clark Duncan' was decent acting. But King Pin was ( White ) just like ''Nick Fury'' was also! I don't think it would be right if they portrayed: The Black Panther as a" Asian Man or other ethnic''. ¬†Years from now if Iron Man is: Vietnamese, Luke Cage is British etc... the origins of what we grew up on may confuse newer generation of comic lovers, as well as the older generation! ¬† Hollywood should keep the origins the same, & if new characters need to be created to fit a plot, then do it! I Loved the Avengers, hate that Captain America doesn't have wings on side of his head! Thor doesn't have his helmet, Superman doesn't have the (S) on the back of his cape, & trunks to go with costume, & Batman as well! ¬† Deadpool is the only one that looks true to his costume! QuickSilver & Scarlet Witch costumes aren't great either! ¬† Everyone has their assessments, I just think that comics that are ( World Wide ) somethings shouldn't be changed!

There's no Telling what he'll bring to us *no pun intended*.¬†  Jessica Alba made a good Invisible Woman, but this Invisible Woman might have potential.¬†  Chris Evans was a pretty good Human Torch, but to be honest, I'd prefer Evans as Captain America over Human Torch. A black Human Torch sounds like a really interesting idea.¬†  Dr. Doom in this trailer looks a lot more intimidating than in the old film.

author: Zhango

text: Blah blah blah. Everybody is ranting and raving about this studio or that race etc. Let's keep it simple. The problem with Fantastic Four is this: Regardless of the quality of Batman v Superman, or Age of Ultron...you simply want to go to the movie theaters to see the successful translation or train wreck. With Fantastic Four, yes, you'll watch it--a special effects superhero movie? Sure, why not!. But you have little interest to see it outside of cable television, a streaming service, or a download. Period. And I'm in love with Kate Mara!  I think Marketing should've just played against this fact and intentionally "shot themselves in the foot," by making it an exclusive fringe movie so that everyone would start chattering on the internet about "what the heck are these crazy people doing!?" They could achieve that by making it R-rated, include adult themes, stronger more realistic language, add nudity (Kate Mara--yes, please!), and increase the intensity of the action and the peril. By catering to a specialized subset of fans rather than dumbing it down for general audiences, more of everyone would want "in," and then be pleasantly surprised that rather than this Fox movie coming off as Marvel-lite, it was its own standalone universe with a different approach, purpose, and narrative to say.  The best way to not whimper behind Marvel, is to stop chasing after them and speak your own unique voice. I'm not interested in seeing a bunch of kids running around 90210, but that's fine. It's all about the execution, like a young Peter Parker/Spiderman. Age and race is irrelevant--there is ZERO need to follow the comic book storylines and character verbatim, despite fanboy cries. No one takes them seriously. But how much more interesting would it have been if the characters were older? Wiser? More broken? With character flaws? Instead of forever existing as Marvel-less, next time, aim for Marvelous.

text: Being someone who grew up with these characters since the 60s, I'm a bit of a purist. ¬†I hate change when it impacts the memories I have of something I enjoy. ¬†After reading the comments below, I can agree and approve of the fact that the characters are younger iterations. ¬†I also don't agree with some of those who dislike the Thing's appearance. ¬†He's rock, the texture of the new render gives him more character. ¬†I am however dismayed at the fact that they became who they are because of interdimensional travel. ¬†If this is to be part of the Marvel universe, they could have used a Dark Matter or Dark Energy experiment. ¬†That way it would fit with the Dark Matter institute that makes an appearance in The Avengers. ¬†Also I don't like the casting. ¬†The two issues I have are the people chosen to play The Torch and The Thing. ¬†The Thing was a tough, stocky person before he was changed and Johnny Storm was caucasian. ¬†I don't say this to be labeled as racist, but if this is indeed supposed to be them as younger individuals, then why change this? ¬†Everyone knows the team and no one had issues.  Now for those of you who are upset about what I said, know ¬†this, I have no issue with a black storm trooper in the new Star Wars film. ¬†I love Star Wars and have no issue with that.  What I hate is the fact that Hollywood has lost a lot of creativity and seems to only be about making re-boots, re-makes and ruining things that were, in their original form, perfect as is. ¬†FF4 has been a questionable film in all of it's incarnations and using Doom in this as the villain right off is mindblowingly dull. ¬†Doom is a great villain, unfortunately he has been misrepresented every time. ¬†They should build up to him and get someone who not only can write him well, but also play him well.  I am a fan of FF4, however I am not very satisfied with this right now. ¬†Hopefully my feeling will change with more media coverage. ¬†Frankly I'm tired of being witness to terrible examples of things I love. ¬†For now, I will try to keep an open mind.
author: Brian Clark

author: Static Alpha

text: You know whats cool? My 11 year old son, has grown up around the FF4 because of me ( a fan since the 70's) and he told me yesterday about this new FF4 movie coming out and how i have to watch the trailer and it looks awesome! He also mentioned how he cant wait to go see it with me and Ben (my favorite character) looks cooler now, but Johnny is still his favorite. The greatest part of this story is that he never mentioned once that Johnny was black. You know why? Because it doesnt matter to our children. I think that is a good thing! Hell, the FF4 has been around since the early 60's!! During those last 50+ years, Johnny has always been white, and Sue has always been his older sister (real, not adopted). Now FOX changes the original character ethnicity to a more "politically correct" line up and everyone seems to get all emotional. It's a MOVIE! They are not REAL, they are F-I-C-T-I-O-N-A-L. Guess what? My son and I are big Blade fans and I'll tell you what, nobody can play a better Blade than Snipes! I wonder what white actor FOX would use if they made Blade 4? Lol.

text: In spite of some of the negative feedback this trailer has gotten (even though it's also got a lot of positive feedback), I am still excited for this movie for one main reason: JOSH TRANK IS THE DIRECTOR. I enjoyed Chronicle and find it interesting to see a film director at the beginning of their career. This is Trank's second movie and I still can't wait to see it. Also, Simon Kinberg as writer after what he did on Days of Future Past is a plus. And the fact that this is a reboot that is very much needed and doesn't feel like the (now pointless) Spider-Man 2012 reboot. This Fantastic Four reboot is looking to be the Batman Begins of 2015 (especially coming out 10 years after Batman Begins).

author: Jadi Nicolas

text: I am a 58 year old man who began reading The Fantastic Four in 1963, when Kirby and Lee started hitting their stride. ( I also met them both, having worked as an artist/inker for Marvel and DC for many years ). It pains me to say this, but even I have to let go of the Silver Age past. The Origin story which seemed plausible in 1961, simply would be laughable today I'm afraid. Having a Black Man as Johnny Storm is NOW and more than that, necessary..! ( and I am Caucasian ). Kirby and Lee were GREAT minds and timeless icons, but it became magic a half-century ago and we all must move on. Dr. Doom as a "gypsy" child who became a mad genius also is a bit worn out theoretically and quite politically incorrect. Kirby was born in 1917 and Stan in 1923 ( I believe ). This is a FAR different world and a FAR different movie audience. If I can be excited, perhaps any of you can. Lee and Kirby, Mickey Mantle and The Beatles are always in my heart, but it is time to let younger minds have their day in the Sun.

text: I guess I could get used to the new Torch. But since Rebel Without A Cause, James Dean, wearing that Red "fire engine" jacket, I guess I have usually associated blonde hair with fire... Or maybe it was the way Dean combed his hair in that movie, making his head look like a lit matchstick?.... Fire... remember that forward pass he throws in the movie, 21 Jumpstreet?¬† Ka-boom.... Guns, are basically bombs, but the energy is focused... like at a target.... Bombs, are chaotic.... no particular target.... simple, "grand-standing".... "terrorist"-like.... random... But guns, are focused at a target.... I guess when a bomb targets a person or organization they should be thought of as snipers.... And when a person randomly fires a gun, he should be thought of as a bomber.... The scene with the car... really?¬† Kind of a stupid way of saying, this guy is into "fire".... why not have him listening to a sermon by Malcolm X rather?¬† No wait, his speeches may have been "incendiary", but his delivery was cool. In contrast, Martin Luther King's speeches were reconciliatory, non-explosive, but his voice - full of fiery passion.¬† An odd contrast, those two. This, new torch, he seems.... cool, quiet.... so, in what sense is he "fiery"?¬† Arsonist?¬† That sounds, criminal.

text: It looks ok, but two things;  1. What is will the poor quality digital effects on the Baxter building? It looks so fake. I've seen better graphics in 80s movies. And then the rest of the digital effects in the movie are great. Wtf? 2. Why does the Flaming Torch have to be black? And why is it like he's the coolest character in the movie? It's like black people always have to be the coolest characters in movies today. I don't understand, it's like they can't be satisfied. They gain the freedom to star in movies, even some of which are their own, and they still have to complain and take over some of our (Marvel fans) movies. Some of us are Marvel fans and are fans of Fantastic 4, and this is just simply not the Fantastic 4 we know. I know they're gonna complain like "all superheroes have to be white" like they always do, but there are black superheroes. In fact, "Black Panther" will be coming to theaters soon (within the next 2 years) and Black Panther is a real cool black super-hero. He doesn't even have a team. You all can obsess over that. There is also Blade who even got his own movie. There is Storm of X-Men and Hancock. But us Fantastic 4 fans know the Flaming Torch as he is and I prefer you would have left him as he is instead of making him a tug of war toy over race. You people have gained plenty of freedom, (even too much now that you look at the sociopolitical disorder currently ravaging our society (just look at Baltimore right now)). We even have a black president. Stop complaining and learn to be happy, won't you?

text: Apparently, "reboot" means to make at least one of the characters black, because it was obviously a mistake in the first place to have 4 superheros that were all white. Whoever wrote the original Fantastic Four (Stan Lee?) was obviously racist for not including a black person. Hey why can't The Thing be Asian? When does it end? How long until Superman is black, or Batman? Get ready, cause it's gonna happen. Hollywood is apparently full of PC apologists that for some reason it's their duty to replace white characters with black ones as often as they can. The whole concept is stupid. There have been all kinds of characters who were black. Dethlok, Storm, Cloak, Power Man, Black Panther (one of my own personal favourites), the second Captain Marvel, and even Iron Man was black for a while. Rather than pandering to the PC crowd and rewriting comic history, why can't we have a superhero movie with a real black character? Eh whatever, this movie will probably be as shitty as the last one anyway.

author: Pedro Marco

text: I support this movie wholeheartedly.  Even before anything was announced, I was eager for this.  Personally, I enjoyed the two previous adaptations although Rise of the Silver Surfer was more memorable, in my opinion.  Unfortunately, it didn't warrant a third film, but thankfully, we have not seen the last of Red, Ben, Sue & Johnny!   Anyway, when the first teaser came out back in late January, I was once again convinced and assured that this had everything to offer.   I've watched & read some of Trank's interviews about this and the process behind refurbishing these characters, and I've got to say, he's got a vision and he's confident about it so why can't that suffice for the others?   It's incontestable that this will be the underdog of the superhero movies this year. No doubt.   And it really bothers me to see people comment over and over again that this is just a carbon copy, a shitty simulacrum of Interstellar (which I saw two weeks back).  It's not fair to the actors or anyone involved to lambast, excoriate & denigrate this movie on account of what little we've been given.  In any case, that may serve to everyone's advantage.  Just consider it.   What I like about this one is that it's going to be bold.  This movie has an identity already that will put it on a level of its own.  Everyone thought that this would be a cerebral take on the FF, but this should be indicative of the humor we've come to recognize in the story of these heroes; being executed in glorious fashion.   I'd've preferred it if they called it ‚ÄúUltimate Fantastic Four: Heroes Reborn‚Äù or something along those lines.  A name like that is enough to bury any ensuing confusions with its predecessor.  Fox & Trank have something here, and I'd like to think that even the skeptics out there hold out so much as a nugget of hope, a modicum of doubt because this may be the Fantastic Four movie we've always wanted.   Whoever reads this, I want you to know that I have no shame in endorsing this upcoming movie, and that you gain more by helping this cause.   If we support this, we not only ensure a sequel, but also expedite the process of getting FF & the X-Men to come together and make more comic book & cinematic history.   This is the golden age.  Let's help. :)

text: Comic book fans are the biggest crybabies ever. Worst than weaboos, video game nerds, and sports fans combined.  Movies don't ever have to be 100% to the source material, and they never have been throughout Hollywood's long history. And if they were, people would still be complaining "Ugh everything's the same, so boring" . And over Marvel's 76 year history, titles such as the X-men, the Avengers, Spider-Man, and the FF have been retconned and rebooted. Marvel doesn't even stick to its own source material. There are many different interpretations and multiverses, yet you purists are complaining about this one? How are you exactly a comic book fan? If you are so entitled as to say that your interpretation is the best, then why you write your own fanfics, make your own movies, or get your college degrees in creative writing and sequential art? If you feel like this movie is SO STRONGLY disrespecting the source material, then why don't you make your own scripts? Your own movies? To judge a movie before it comes out is so stupid.  And how exactly will this movie bomb at the box office because a bunch of comic book fans are whining? Superhero movies are geared towards the general audience; general audiences are the ones who will put the most money out. And with this large trend of superhero movies coming out every year to the large approval of the general audience, this movie will still make a ton of money. Quit being so entitled.

text: I can guarantee this movie will be better than the last two FF films, but it'd take a miracle for this film to be great. The casting is more than questionable, we don't really know the story yet, and there's a chance Marvel will buy back the FF property soon, which will make this film like the Amazing Spider-Man series (unneeded, and forgotten). The only bright lights I see in this film are the tone, and the director (Josh Trank, the guy that directed Chronicle, which was probably the best original superhero film I've ever seen, right next to Unbreakable.)

text: The point of a reboot is to set things on the correct path, fix the story, get better actors for characters, ones that might be cheaper to get back for sequels too... You know, that kind of stuff... Instead, the sibling element is gone now between Sue and Johnny, they all look like they're still in diapers and the supposed "muscle" line, just doesn't work. That actor should've been more a little bigger if he's supposed to turn into the Thing. My ranting aside, I'm tired of them screwing over correct Marvel characters (like making them black or white when they shouldn't be) to make people happy about race... Instead, why not make movies of black super heroes? Where is Goliath? He deserves something, or Bishop, OR Luke Cage.... I just don't get it...

text: Seeing how this trailer gives us inklings of the humor we've come to love about the FF, I really hope they make small, passing jokes or references to the three previous films as a way of saying ‚ÄúWe know you're talking, but we're going to let you continue your little diatribes because we're about to redefine the Fantastic Four in a live, cinematic context!‚Äù.. :D   I saw the cartoon they made for them a few years back, & I hope that this Thing still has that clumsiness with people and even himself while adjusting to his new form.  The drama and the realism that they're going for evinces dangerous ambitions in the eyes of many, but for myself, it is something that I welcome dearly simply because the goal remains to introduce these characters to our modern settings and our particular eras in ways that they could still coexist with the times.  Life is dark, but they must counterbalance the reality with levity.  That's the experience they should offer, an experience with every flavor of emotion and humanity so that it speaks to the audience.   I'm also curious as to what the final suits will look like given the fact that Miles said we would be seeing them later on in the film.  Personally, my suggestion is that they go for the ‚ÄòUltimate‚Äô style with a bit of a 60's edge and maybe even take some cues from Future Foundation!!  Whatever happens, I believe the costume designers stand a great chance in reinventing the visual appeal of these characters.  That being said, I really wish I worked in the film industry.  I really do.  If I were involved with this movie, I'd make so many ‚Äúslight‚Äù changes to their marketing plan.   For starters, the logo is too bold.  It doesn't grab you‚Äîright away.  The logo should embellish that visual appeal I mentioned above.  And I like that they put the 4 in the word itself, but they really should've used the logo from the current comic to match it, and then they could change the white letters to a mix of silver and black with a blue outline.  That would be neat, unique, and properly attuned with the presentation they're going for!!  Imagine it for a second and tell me if that wouldn't look cool on all the merchandise!!  When you carry over the two & get down to circles and squares, it is a comic book movie at heart.  So why alienate that core if the goal is to convince that large market, the large market that remains disheartened by previous efforts to cement the FF as a Hollywood mainstay in the superhero department?  Why do that?  Embrace the history and add to its legacy in the process!   Truth be told, I'm not too concerned with the anticipated X-Men crossovers that people want to see.  The first thing to stress is whether or not this movie succeeds.  At this point, of all the Marvel movies coming out, this one appears to be the true wildcard, the anomaly, the outlier as it were.  The primary objective is to get people riled up for this.  Supporters and detractors alike.  Get them riled up, get them to invest and the rest is anyone's guess, really.   I just hope they aren't pressured into an X-Men crossover or producing a movie with an X-Men-esque tone.  Be true to their spirits, but apply it in terms of 2015 and the world today.  Make it organic and fun.   Guardians of the Galaxy should serve a testament to everything I'm saying.   If anyone would like to agree or disagree, please comment. :)  However, I'd like constructive conversation here.  I'd like to know if I'm alone on many of these concerns I have.

text: I'm just confused. How are Johnny and Sue brother and sister if Johnny is African American? I guess they could have one parent in common, though Johnny doesn't really look mixed and Sue is white as a sheet. Why didn't they just make Ben Grimm an African American? That would work. But, that's only a secondary complaint against the constant rewriting of classic comic characters. My main complaint is: why are they all so YOUNG?! I guess young people are the box office draw. I guess. But aren't the comic book geeks more the 30+ male crowd? At least, Reed Richards should be older, with the iconic silver sideburns. I'd like to see a Fantastic Four movie set in the 1960's, when the great team of Kirby and Lee created it. They did that with X-Men: First Class, and it worked really well. And lastly, I can't tell you how UNIMPORTANT my comments are! LOL

text: People who have a problem with them changing the race should just relax! I could see if Hollywood announced they were doing a John F. Kennedy movie, and they got WILL SMITH to play Kennedy? We all know John Kennedy was WHITE, not BLACK. Why? Because he was a REAL person, JONNY STORM ISN'T! HE'S A FREAKING CARTOON! He's NOT real! The artist in the comics can choose to make him whatever color they want with the stroke of a pen, which they actually DO all the time in the comics. Sometimes there are multiple incarnations of superheros, all, looking different, all, ¬†at the same time like Harley Quinn for instance. There are three different versions of her in the comics, ALL, looking completely different! Why wouldn't they do the same for the live action film, and find the best actor, despite what race he is. If you've seen Fruitvail Station you know Michael B. Jordan is the real deal!
author: Nightwalker

text: It's funny, I don't recall anyone having a problem with the first two FF movies when they put Jessica Alba in a ridiculous BLONDE wig and terrible BLUE contact lenses and we were suppose to believe that she and Chis Evans could really be brother and sister? On what planet? Even though she is only half Mexican, she looks 100% Mexican! I remember watching those movies thinking am I the only one who sees this clearly Mexican girl being made to look WHITE? It was hard to watch, and I literally felt embarrassed for her, watching those goofy movies!
author: Nightwalker

text: I think it's a step in the right direction that Hollywood in the time the first FF movie came out (around 2005) to now, ¬†has went from attempting to make a Mexican actress appear white, to completely changing a character's race, opting ¬†to just cast the best actors for the roles!
author: Nightwalker

text: At the end of the day nobody really cares what race the character is. I'm a big horror movie fan so, for instance, if they remade A Nightmare on Elm Street (again) and cast a Latino actor to play Freddy Kruger nobody would give two craps, just as long as he has that red\green sweater, that fedora and of course those all important RAZOR HANDS! Those are the only things we really care about! Jonny Storm could be BLACK, WHITE or PURPLE just as long as he turns into a FLAME and not some icecube or something!
author: Nightwalker

text: The casting looks awful, the studio clearly thinks that "darker tone" means it'll automatically be a good movie, and it's yet another reboot telling an origin story that audiences already saw in the 2005 film.¬† I'll be surprised if this film doesn't meet the same fate as the Amazing Spider-Man series.¬† Looks like another mediocre and unnecessary reboot.¬† And yes, I'm aware the original films weren't good, but why reboot a series when this looks just as mediocre?

text: Just saw the movie. Its not great, but to be honest, its not the worst. I think the reason it is getting bad reviews is because the advertisements built up peoples expectations into something that the movie wasn't. Just because the film doesn't meet these expectations doesn't make it a bad film, just a disappointment.¬† The film does however lack in pacing as the films action sequences rack up about 20 mins of the entire film and the rest is exposition.¬† I did get a sense of character chemistry between the actors, even the actor who played Doom was believable but sadly lacked the development behind his motives.¬† All in all the film just needed some rounding out, and this would have made a decent film. I believe the film was forced released by the studio and so things where rushed and the final product became a mess.

text: "I gotta say it's fun having you here" ‚Ä¶ "really?" ‚Ä¶ "no"  Love how trailers just completely rewrite the movie - that exchange there is actually compiled of two completely different conversations, in order to make a joke in the trailer that totally misrepresents Sue's character and her relationship with Reed.  In the actual film, the person she says fun having around is her brother Johnny.     Also, the "how long till he's in‚Ä¶ two minutes, might be a little less" exchange is edited to look like Reed is supervising one of Thing's military incursions‚Ä¶ in the actual movie, we never even see this incursion, and Reed is actually telling a character how long it will take him to revise code"   False advertising, honestly...

text: this movies was complete bull. seriously, don't waste your time watching it. What good is it to just start the whole movie series over with different actors? Pointless. the graphics were disappointing, and way better in the original movie series. These actors did one heck of a job trying to pull off a sloppy written script. Everything about this movie was wrong. It felt rushed, writers didn't really put in that much effort in writing out the characters, i mean they couldn't even get "the thing" to look realistic. The plot was confusing and a mess. For millions of dollars to go into a single movie, you would expect it t be decent enough that you won't have to walk out of the theatre half way through the movie. Couldn't even keep the story line in tact. Had to change the whole thing.

text: I loved this film. I think I remember my only issue with it being that they created a villain that gave me the chills, and got rid of him very easily and quickly. It felt like the film was missing a third act (or the third act was cut short), that we didn‚Äôt get to witness the limits of the antagonist. There was great potential. I loved it until the second it ended. He spent a very short time on earth, and didn‚Äôt even leave the facility through which he entered our planet (if I remember correctly). The fight was mostly in the ‚Äúother world‚Äù and was brief. Would‚Äôve loved to see some widespread destruction on earth, enough to make us feel something and to have gotten to know the villain more. Anyway, this is just my opinion. Forgive my use of ‚Äúvillain‚Äù and ‚Äúother world‚Äù. Don‚Äôt know much about the background and my memory might not be what it used to be.  P.s. I have no issues with the cast.

text: The reason why i don't hate the film is that it's actually a *science movie* instead a action-blockbuster like from the MCU, which fits perfect to the Fantastic Four. Making the plot about science and discoveries without misplaced humor and everything. Of course, the script could have been better, but the film itself and the casting are not as bad as people say. Director Josh Tank allegedly made a totally different film, but the studio turned it all upside down. We already see shots in this trailer that didn't make it to the final version.I want to be honest: i'm actually still waiting for the *Director's Cut*.

text: People who actually really liked it and I have nothing against that but in my opinion I thought this was the worst movie yet. And usually I love movies, sometimes my family wants to see a movie but I don't want to see it but then once it's over I actually end up really liking it. But for this I wanted to see it and once it was over I was relieved and very disappointed at the same time. One of the reasons I didn't like it was because I couldn't really follow the storyline I feel like I didn't know what was happening and also in most marvel or superhero movies there's at least a little humor in it I didn't find anything funny nor entertaining... sorry I just had to get this off my chest ... hopefully I didn't hurt anyone's feelings that much

text: Guys let's be honest here & let's state facts while we are at it...  This Fantastic 4 movie was a nightmare for Fox & Its director, It performed horribly at the box office & ruined the chances of this young director getting bigger projects...  The film isn't that hard to make considering Marvel can make a film like Infinity war look amazing...  The cast was brilliant I'll admit that, The story worked for the most part until Reed leaves them behind & after that its a nightmare of a movie...  There was no reason for Doctor Doom to be there & he basically comes back later in the film which makes no sense at all...  It was fucken mess!!! Plain & Simple & for those bitching about it would be hard to make, Look at the avengers & now this film... This movie would be a walk in the park by Fox's standards
